Content: Ray: It'll be all right, Tim.
Hansen: It's all right. We'll figure this out.
Tim: Are you saying I shouldn't do it?
Hansen: Don't do it. Don't do it.
Ray: We'll make it work.
Tim: You're just mad because if I did this it would not solve the problem for you guys.
Hansen: It just makes it worse actually. Ray: Yeah.
Hansen: That's right. It makes it easier for you.
Ray: There're still pickup lines that haven't been written, aren't there?
[Music] Tim: I really am trying everything to make sure the game comes out this year.
Ray: December. What are we in, October, November?
Yeah, I know that's not gonna happen.
Tim: I gotta finish.
I'm so close to being done with the dialogue for the game which would be a huge milestone in my life
because all I can think about is the dialogue for this game.
There's a lot of dialogue in this game.
Okay, we're gonna start.
Weeklies, here we are, back on the project.
Hey, guess what. I finished all the dialogue for the game.
It's awesome. Yay!
[Clapping] That's a relief.
Crook: Finally.
Schafer: Well, I mean you didn't have to put it that way, but yeah, yeah, finally.
Crook: Someone had to say it!
I know I was going on my calendar today and there's a big recurring appointment for Reds writing and I went and I deleted it.
Oh, my God, this is exciting.
I'm never gonna write again.
Never write again. Never write again.
So actually I'm playing through the game right now and I'm making notes of what dialogue I need to write.
Other than that I'm totally done.
[Music] And then Tim nobly finished the last of the dialogue
and everyone was happy forever, the end.
And that's the end of that chapter.
Does anybody have any questions?
Broken Age, broken Age.
That's our rousing chant, broken age.
Bye.
Peck: What's new, man?
We have gotten a butt ton of writing from Tim.
Crook: It's really good writing.
And the performances that we've gotten back are really good and so that kind of puts the pressure on you
as an animator that you want to do that writing and those performances justice.
So that's, that's pressure, but good pressure.
It feels like things are moving smoothly.
It feels that way.
Anna: We're like finishing in record time.
We're actually ahead of schedule in a lot of ways which is like, you know, pretty rare for us because usually we're pretty slammed.
Lee: Yes, I can show you some mockups that we're working on in Vella, yeah, yeah.
This scene here is where Vella starts.
Players have already seen this, you know, the split screen at the very end of the game, and this is kind of what that scene continues as.
And then this is the first puzzle you see here is her skill here.
So this is a fairly elaborate puzzle that the player has to hit, and so a lot of this is just breakdowns of how it all works.
So we have the Hex Pals are returning.
Of course. I love the Hex Pals so I'm hoping to do more with them this time.
I think the Hex Pals and the Spoon, that stuff was all the big hits, like the surprise, like everyone loved these little side characters.
We have now heard a lot more feedback on that first act than you ever would if you were just gonna release it at once
because it's been out in the wild and people have lived with it.
We've lived it for a while so we have more perspective on it.
Maybe that means the choices we're making for Act 2 are just a little bit better formed than they would've been if it was just,
you know, one big push.
And then just a lot of scenes in Act 2, I can walk you around some of those if you want to see.
I can show you some with the spaceship stuff.
So we've tried to go through and make it look like you're driving by the countryside and damage some of the rooms.
Schafer: Exciting, really going places.
Petty: If you go in that doorway on the left there's some ambience there.
Schafer: It's too bad we have puzzles in both those places because it'd be funny to see a room that was there before and then just isn't there,
like so the door is open like to the avalanche area.
No, we need that one.
Or to the like the friendship circle where something just opens and then it just like [explosive noise] just space in there.
It could just be you open it and it's just the shards of a room and there's just a bunch of yarn pals hanging on.
Aaahh!
They're just stuck out there.
Petty: I was thinking that for any of the rooms like that, that we should have the doors and then continue on in animation state
where they can't quite close or open.
They're just kinda...
Schafer: They're closing over a severed human foot.
Peck: There's some cool game play that's like nonstandard stuff where like you're floating in zero gravity
and so like you play around with the physics of that.
So this is one of those instances where we were in a brainstorm meeting and we were like what if the whole ship just like rotated
because it's taking off, right?
And everyone was like, oh shit.
Offscreen: Once you solve that and you get up here and the doors open, that's when we do the;
and then we cut to the old scene and now you're floating above it.
You're like, how do I get down there?
Schafer: So she could be spinning.
So there could be a timing thing that you have to do a certain thing which is aim a certain direction.
Petty: We could have like the boy's magnetic boots stuck on the hole, you know, if we wanted to use those somehow.
Schafer: And you just like want to drift over to it and grab it and use it to like.
Petty: Oh, wait, there's a scarf on the suit.
So if you could take the scarf off the floating suit.
Peck: Not exactly your typical adventure game.
Walk to "A" to "B".
Crap, I missed it. It's a timing puzzle.
You have to like line up the rotations of these two things.
Damn it. I missed it again.
I anticipate a lot of amazing play testing feedback from this with people being like fuck that mini game.
We've also had to think outside the box in terms of like, especially because we're reusing environments so we can't just make
a new environment that supports really difficult puzzles.
We have to use the environments we've already made.
And so yeah, we consciously wanted to try and, try and do things that we hadn't done before.
Let's have a puzzle that goes across multiple scenes.
Let's like rotate the ship.
Let's play with the fact that we're on a spaceship.
We're in space.
Maybe there's no gravity.
There's this really weird plot device that we have in Act 1 where like the mom could magically manipulate everything on the ship.
What if Vella could gain access to that system?
Like, that's a really cool idea to pursue.
And like a lot of really great puzzle ideas came out of that kind of, that kind of thinking.
Kipnis: It's just like ways to interact with the ship or to see the same space in a completely original context.
Schafer: And the team is starting to wire out the first few puzzles for Vella on the spaceship now.
That's mostly what was going on.
Reds. Unless I forgot something.
Anyone want to do anything else?
Okay, now I have to go the bad and not fun part of the meeting where I have some bad news to tell you about,
someone else leaving the company which is never very fun.
Isa is leaving and oh, man, come on up here, Isa.
Stamos: So I just want to let you know I'll be cheering Double Fine on, and I've loved my time here.
[Applause] Schafer: Luckily we have Matt Hanson who was our right-hand man,
and he's stepping right into the role of being the VP of product development so he's doing that job which means he probably has less time
to do producer type stuff on Broken Age.
Yeah, I might technically be short a producer.
I hadn't thought about that. Now I'm terrified.
I'm never gonna make December. We'll see.
That'll delay them in making that schedule that says we can't make December so that way I can hopefully get the game done before anyone realizes it's impossible.
I think we're gonna make December.
We'll never make December.
Shut up. Shut up.
Ow, that really hurts.
Peck: That's like above my pay grade, dude.
Russell: Like, what do I think?
Just for me or the whole game?
Offscreen: The whole game I guess.
Malena and I think it's gonna be March.
I'm not sure who thought ever December was really gonna be it.
Offscreen: Tim. Russell: Yeah.
Kipnis: Yeah, I don't, I don't actually know the release date at this point.
I think it's gonna be largely driven by how long it takes for all of the animations to be final
because the animators are gonna be slammed pretty hard since some of the voice is getting into the game so late unfortunately.
Schafer: Yeah, some of the VO talent has been harder to get in the studio than others,
and so you have a couple big characters that have yet to be recorded and that holds up all the cut scenes.
We're looking at cut scene layouts together so that Ray can know whether they're ready to go.
What's a layout, Ray?
Crook: A layout is a first pass of the scene with the characters all in their sort of place and with the dialogue timed out.
Schafer: The rough cameras, the timing, but none of the animation.
Crook: Yeah, none of the animation.
Schafer: Whipped Cream Hill fail.
Crook: She gets it too.
Schafer: Who did that one?
Crook: Miyuki.
Schafer: Is it the same?
Crook: It's the exact same rig, yeah.
I think it's funny that it's exactly the same.
Schafer: If we can just repeat the same, she can have a whole different; I can't even think of a word.
Crook: I think the joke's funny because it is the same. Schafer: Mm-hmm.
Crook: If you want something different.
Schafer: No, it's good.
And then we're just finishing up on the Alpha and the G-2 act and then we've got to do the finale.
Petty: It's a whole area, new characters.
It's probably a lot of cut scene work.
It's probably a ton of animation.
When it's not really a 3-D world and you have to stage things specifically and you don't want to paint a million scenes,
a lot of it really comes down to exactly what is going on in the writing and the puzzles.
Schafer: Even though we haven't been storyboarding a lot in the process, like this would be an important one to do
because I know Peter's already talking about musical score and that London, I mean that Melbourne Symphony Orchestra gig is gonna come up.
And I think this would be a great place to have special music and not use existing cues and stuff.
So hopefully we can actually storyboard it, timing it out in the animatic and commit to that, lock that,
and then have them build a score to that while we're making it.
Do you want to go shot by shot then?
Okay, so that's the opening shot, just like here's the situation.
It's happened.
And then we cut into an interior shot and I was thinking interior because I was hoping we'd just fake it and it shows a bunch of red smoke because
like they're in the room that's the hottest so it's like smoke is coming up.
Crook: So yeah, so this is the animatic with Lee's storyboards.
It's very actiony, very dramatic.
It'll require some really good performance from whoever ends up animating it.
To really just sit down and have a big, juicy acting scene, for me that's, I get the most enjoyment out of that
because that's when your personality can come out in a way.
Yeah, it's gonna be a lot of work.
It should be.
Finales should always be a lot of work because it's 3-1/2 minutes.
So that might not sound like a lot, but that's actually, that's a really long scene.
It's a really long scene.
Because if we're really locking the timing down, which is kind of scary.
Petty: Yeah, I'm not sure why we'd have to have the music scored before we get the dialogue unless the deadlines are such that.
Crook: I think the music scores, because they're gonna be scoring Grim at the same time, right?
Isn't that was this whole idea is?
Petty: Oh, is it?
Crook: I think that's what the deal is because they only want to book the orchestra once.
Crook: Isn't the idea they're gonna book the orchestra once and they're gonna do Grim and this at the same time?
Crook: We were talking about whether we could take it to the next level or not which would be maya animatic.
Petty: We certainly can, but there's a ridiculous amount of work right now for all this other stuff.
And so it's just a matter of where we're putting; I can't.
I have the storyboard.
I can't really describe all this to Bagel and then have him storyboard it remotely so I have to storyboard it.
No, I mean, it can be done.
It's just; I think it just gets down to the conversation we always sort of have and don't have an answer for which is date.
Petty: Well, it's the only thing that a hard deadline.
Yeah, and then I've been working with Vic on the all timeline stuff too.
Yeah, I think we're trying to put together like a whole new pass on it and we've talked with most of the leads and everything already about stuff.
So probably within the next week or so we'll have a, ooh, bless you.
Probably in the next week or so we'll have a new full timeline to share.
I think it's pretty safe to say at this point already that it's not December; like we've already talked about that with pretty much everybody.
Schafer: Not me.
Rice: Yeah, we've talked about it multiple times.
Tim: Yeah, totally ambushed me with that December thing.
Well, they've all been talking about how they don't feel like we're gonna make December and we probably aren't, but I haven't seen any date.
You know, it's like it's all hunches.
It's all people's hunches versus hunches, but they're supposed to be doing a waterfall schedule
which is like all the dependencies linked out and that will show us ending a certain month.
And hopefully it's not April.
But it's almost like if you believe it's going to be March then it will be March.
And if you're trying to hit December it'll be hopefully January.
But if everyone's just like we're not even trying to make December then we'll slip even worse.
So it's hard to kind of keep a sense of urgency on the project when you feel like; because we're spending our own money on it now
so it's not like a publisher milestone, like the milestone's due in December and everyone just always takes that seriously.
And when we have something that's an internal milestone or a milestone that only Double Fine is holding you accountable for,
people are like, well, we've got an extra week and stuff.
And that's a hard, a hard thing to instill that sense of like taking a milestone seriously even when it's just us because it's more money.
Every week that it goes it costs more money.
And it's longer the backers will have to wait and it's, you know, the longer that we have to put off other things we want to do.
So I still push for getting it done as soon as possible.
Rice: Yeah, there's a lot of work left.
It's probably not gonna be December, but we're figuring out when it would be.
It looks like the thing we're thinking, we're hoping for December, is we've got two more weeks on Act 2 stuff,
and then the finale stuff we're thinking is like six for like a really solid safe Alpha.
And with all the like holiday stuff in before the end of the year and everything, that kind of takes us almost exactly to the end of the year.
Then you have the matter of closing it out is what we're trying to figure out now, so okay.
Annable: I could've told you like a day back in July it wasn't gonna happen for December.
Schafer: I'm gonna wait till I see all the numbers.
Now it's at, well, we're really close to when it should be wrapping up if it's gonna be done in December.
We should have the voice in, and we don't have the final three characters in.
We're doing that next week.
On Reds I am going down to help with the VO recording which is happening Wednesday, Thursday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday of this week.
That's for Vella.
Brown: I don't feel confident about that at this point.
I'll be honest.
I'm more comfortable saying what I really think because I don't want to say it on camera.
I'll just be totally blunt.
And I'll try to get us out of the studio time that we've purchased for the next four days.
I'm working on it.
Crook: So Tim flew down to record dialogue, Vella in particular, and she had a family emergency.
And so that kind of messes everything up.
I mean, it's not her fault.
People have family emergencies.
But it definitely kind of went into panic mode a little bit.
Schafer: Do you see I made a tiny gun to shoot myself?
It looks effective on camera.
Crook: There you go. That's better.
Open your mouth.
It'll be all right, Tim.
Hansen: It's all right. We'll figure this out.
Russell: Vella, for her part of Act 2 is in almost every cut scene so there's very few cut scenes that she's actually not in.
And if Malena has us up to date as of today, everything that's red hasn't been recorded yet.
And you can guess who this might be.
This is Vella.
This is why we were kind of freaking out.
That's part of the reason why I made that document, just to figure out, okay, what can we do?
What can we sort of do and may have to reanimate a little bit later?
And what's just, we just have to have the voice?
Otherwise it's just gonna be tough.
Crook: So anyway we're gonna animate to some scratch.
We're gonna not animate some scenes with Vella.
It's gonna be a mixture of things.
We're gonna be juggling a little bit and then hopefully the first week of December that's what we've been promised.
The first week of December we'll get the recordings done for Vella.
Tim: Which is really frustrating because we're so late with that dialogue and keep being even later.
It was nothing something we wanted to do.
Annable: Waiting for her, at a certain point it really, really hurts us and I feel like we're already beyond,
like way beyond where we need to be for her recording.
Crook: We'd have to kind of maybe push everybody off of the project onto some other projects because you don't want to be sitting around burning through money, right?
We have to be working on something all the time.
I mean, it all rides on that December, right?
It rides on the recording actually happening in December.
Annable: And so if she's not available I think we need to have a second actor cast who is also on hold for the same days
that we're putting Masasa on hold when she returns.
And if Masasa is unavailable then we have to go into the studio with that backup person.
Schafer: A lot of people on the team are saying we should recast, should recast Vella with an actress that we know we can get and be ready.
I'd be fine with it but now it just bugs me to think of Vella having two voices because there's no such thing as a real sound-alike.
You can sound kind of like it, but I think Masasa has a real unique voice and I think players would just know.
They would play the first act and then the second act would have a different actress, and it would be that way forever.
It would always be that way.
Annable: It sucks, but I don't want an actor to be responsible for causing so much chaos to our schedule.
Schafer: So changing Vella feels horrible to me so I'm fighting for keeping the original actress,
and I'm hoping she will come through for me.
I'm going into L.A. again to see if the magical gopher will come out of its hole and record some dialogue.
We don't know what's gonna happen.
But I just go down and we see if she shows up.
Rice: And Tim is reporting right now?
Has anyone heard? Has he sent an email yet?
Crook: We know she showed up.
Rice: She did? Okay. She's there. Awesome.
Crook: So that's a good step.
Schafer: Back to the booths.
Moyo: A really big explosion.
I like it when she schemes.
Moyo: Hey, President Ugly.
Is that a dig or is that actually his name?
Schafer: It's totally a dig.
You're pretty casual, like, hey, what's up?
Moyo: Everybody thanks you.
[Music] Hansen: So this meeting is to talk about the schedule
for finishing the rest of Act 2.
So I've met with Vic and Malena and Greg to talk through the remaining work and to put it all on a timeline to see when the thing's finishing.
This should be fairly accurate because you're updated this just recently, right?
Romero: This is every discussion we've had, every wonderful change to our plans that's come up.
It's all on there.
Schafer: We thought it was going to be April so this is actually good news.
Hansen: It's April to release the game because it takes 3 weeks to manufacture.
But this is when development will be done which is...
Petty: Manufacture?
Hansen: Yep, so we're gonna do physical disks.
Petty: Oh, that's right so it has to be simultaneous now, right?
Hansen: That's part of the deal.
Bailey: So we did a deal with Nordic which is yet to be released, but that's cool.
So our deal with Nordic is that they're gonna handle retail distribution of the game in Europe but also here.
So they have some relationships with retailers like Best Buy and other really huge big box stores,
and it'd be really exciting to see Broken Age show up there.
The way it's actually working out is once we're done with the PC version we can ship it over to them
and they have a very quick, just a few week turnaround which is exciting.
And during that time we're working on the other platforms to get them ready.
So like, you know, when you bought it, whoever's bought it on whatever platform, the hope is everybody can experience the conclusion together.
So that's the goal. We'll see how close we get.
Hansen: So as you can see this takes us basically to the end of the year to get the game to Alpha.
And then we would transition on to beta work when we return from the holidays.
And then we have six weeks of bug fixing and polish work at the end.
This is traditionally how long we've needed for all of our projects.
There might be some room to pull that in but I do think that the game needs that much time
in order to address all of the play test feedback, bug fixing and polish work.
Schafer: Have you gone over any of this with Justin yet?
Hansen: Only the end date.
Schafer: What kind of face did he make when you talked to him about the end date?
Did he smile? Hansen: No.
Petty: So somewhere between constipation and Defcon 4. Hansen: Yeah.
Schafer: He also only smiles when things are really bad.
Hansen: It was not a happy face. I'll say that.
Schafer: That's the thing.
The information, I'm just wondering is what; financially can we go to this date or can't we?
Because before we were talking about December and he was kind of like we can't go beyond that because of financial reasons.
And so that's what I would like to hear from him is what happens if we go to this date.
Hansen: Anything else? Tim, do you have anything else?
Schafer: Some inspiring words of wisdom. No.
Hey, guys, how's it going?
I'm getting a strong sense people are trying to give me the message that it's a risk to hit December.
It's gonna be tight to make December.
That's just me reading between the lines of that meeting.
Anyway it's gonna be over soon one way or the other.
[Music] Peck: You getting this?
This is good shit.
